title: 108_hr3357
content: The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to include a new section allowing servicemembers to terminate residential purchase contracts and certain consumer contracts entered into before military service or before permanent change of station or deployment orders. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to allow servicemembers to terminate contracts, including leases of motor vehicles, upon entering military service or receiving military orders. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to allow servicemembers to terminate contracts, including leases, upon entering military service or receiving military orders for a period of not less than 90 days. This includes telecommunications contracts for cellular phone service, cable, or satellite. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 allows servicemembers to terminate contracts for cellular phone service, cable, or satellite television service, or internet service if they enter military service for a period of not less than 90 days or receive orders for a permanent change of station outside of their current location. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 allows servicemembers to terminate contracts for various services if they enter military service for 90 days or receive orders for a permanent change of station outside the continental United States. This includes contracts for the purchase of real property for residential purposes. Termination of contracts is outlined in the Act. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 allows servicemembers to terminate contracts for various services if they enter military service for 90 days or receive orders for a permanent change of station outside the continental United States. Termination of a contract involves delivering a written notice to the other party, with specific requirements for leases of motor vehicles. Delivery of notice can be done by hand, private business carrier, or placing the notice in an envelope. The termination of the lease is effective upon meeting the requirements of subsection (c), while termination of other contracts is effective upon delivery of the notice. In the case of contract termination, unpaid amounts preceding the effective date must be paid prorated. For motor vehicle leases, no early termination charge is allowed, but unpaid taxes, fees, and other liabilities must be settled by the lessee. Any person who seizes or holds the property of a person in military service after lawful termination of a contract may face penalties. Any person who seizes or holds the property of a person in military service after lawful termination of a contract may face penalties under title 18, United States Code, including fines or imprisonment for up to one year. The remedies provided in this section do not preclude other available remedies for wrongful conversion, such as consequential or punitive damages.
